docs.lead_paragraph: DELTA BURKE examined the starchy treasure before her, extended two of her perfectly manicured fingers and did something that, for a long and haunted stretch of her past, she would not do in public, at least not without fearing the titters of tabloids and feeling the lash of her own shame. She grabbed hold of a French fry. She dragged it through ketchup. And then, without apology or visible regret, she ate it.

headline.main: She Waited To Exhale; Now She Can

docs.abstract: Frank Bruni interviews actress Delta Burke, who talks about her journey into obesity, self-acceptance and image adjustment after spending years trying to fit ingenue mold using diet pills and purging; Burke has come to terms with her larger self as have several other actresses, once known as svelte; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The actress Delta Burke, who is now starring in "Steel Magnolias" on Broadway, discusses her conflicted relationship with food.

docs.lead_paragraph: Already one of the most costly civil cases ever prosecuted by the Justice Department, the racketeering trial against the tobacco industry, now in its seventh month, is being heard in two courts and could reach a third, raising questions about what the government might gain with a victory. Testimony continues in the Federal District Court here in a nonjury trial to determine whether the companies hid the adverse health effects of cigarettes for 50 years, as the government contends. Meanwhile, an appeal is already under way to determine the extent of liability if the trial judge rules against the companies.

headline.main: Remedies Emerging as Issue in Federal Tobacco Case

docs.abstract: Justice Dept continues to prosecute one of most costly civil cases in history, racketeering trial against tobacco industry, now in its seventh month; legal experts and lawmakers debate court remedies versus legislation, such as giving FDA authority over tobacco (M)
docs.snippet: The costly racketeering trial being prosecuted by the Justice Department against the tobacco industry is raising questions about what the government might gain with a victory.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare spending for doctors' services shot up 15 percent last year, and beneficiaries will have to pay premiums of $89 a month in 2006, up $11 from the current level, the Bush administration said Thursday. Doctors are billing Medicare for longer, more intensive office visits, more laboratory tests, more frequent and complex imaging procedures and more prescription drugs given to patients in their offices, the administration said.

headline.main: Medicare Costs Rise, So Premiums Will, Too

docs.abstract: Bush administration says Medicare spending for doctors' services shot up 15 percent last year, and beneficiaries will have to pay premiums of $89 a month in 2006, up $11 from current level; federal officials say Medicare will cut payments for each physician service by 4.3 percent next year unless Congress intervenes; doctors say if cuts take effect, many physicians would be less willing to take elderly and disabled patients covered by Medicare; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Medicare spending for doctors' services shot up 15 percent last year, and beneficiaries will have to pay premiums of $89 a month in 2006, the Bush administration said.
